reviews.review_text: Yes!! I've been waiting for this title for quite a while so I am tickled pink that it is finally in the store!   This little 55mb gem is brought to you by the creator of '10000000' for an affordable $3(currently on sale).   The object of the game is simple: You must build a boat.  Much like it's predecessor, you journey though a side scrolling dungeon completing tasks and sliding matching tiles for bonuses/items etc.   Excellent time waster if you're looking for something to sort of casually play without putting a lot of thought into overly complicated mechanics.   There's my short and sweet review!  FIN

Nice fast-paced match-3 game, if you have played 10.000.000, you already know.  It's addictive as RPGs can be, having in common with them stats and unlockable upgrades.  What's new in this game? In this game you can move tiles while other ones that you have already matched are still breaking, that is YMBAB is even more fast-paced than his predecessor; however the game is easier, since you have many little tasks, never as difficult as reaching 10.000.000 points.  In the case you are up for more challenge, after beating the game you can start over with the game being harder, but be wary: this is not a new game+, you lose everything! There is also a little gift midrun if you choose to restart... and there are other secrets in the game... (litterally called secrets by it)  There are many little differences that sum up to became an entirely new game (I don't want to spoil everything), so it's reccomended to people that played the first game too.  The only thing I don't like is the start... why am I on a boat and still I have to build a boat? Why are there monsters with me on it and why are they helping me?  Well, we will never know... but this doesn't matter, because the YMBAB is fun. ; )  P.S. How could I have forgotten the music?! The music in this game is great! I'll probably keep playing to hear that.

I'm not sure I can reccomend this game, its nearly identical to 10,000,000... except this one removes the score requirements and your rank advancement is entirely based on finishing all the quests on a tier. Then the end game seems to be an unaided quest through 500 meters? 500 units? 500 steps? 500 SOMETHINGS to finish the one feature of this boat building simulator that you'd find in evoland... I'd spoil it, but its already spoiled...  Also this game lies, you don't build a boat. Last I checked it takes wood, and stone... things you got in 10,000,000 to build a boat... in this game you don't get any wood, or any stone... so how the hell do you build a boat? SERIOUSLY  I'm still trying to figure out how you go from a canoe to a boat... YOU GET NO MATERIALS TO UPGRADE IT... AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH   This game should be You Must Watch Others Build a Boat, then put some cutscenes in... otherwise no way I'd recommend this failure of a boat building simulator.

The graphic is ugly but the game is funny: yes, there is a bit of grinding but it makes sense to have it because the goal of the game is just spending few minutes without having to think.  By the way, you don't build anything: the boat builds itself when you unlock specific goals. It is just a 3 match game...

EightyEightGames is quickly becoming one of my favorite developers. 10,000,000 was an excellent fresh idea on some old concepts in a nice fun package. You must build a boat is a sequel of sorts to 10,000,000 with the same dungeon crawling, connect x number puzzle game with very bright and addictive game play plus so very much more without spending an extra dime for it. The panick as you can't find a match while trying to defeat the next enemy so you can get that next upgrade or get to that next level of the dungeon is rewarding and tense. It feels Fun. In a day of ♥♥♥ hair waving graphics and novel sized story telling, Fun is a commodity as rare as gold and this game...is Fun. I want to play one more round. I want to get that next upgrade. Highly Recommended for Quick, Rewarding Fun. Just Fun.

I love this game. I had not played 10.000.000 so I had no idea what I was getting myself into. But what a game! Its short, only like 6 hours of gameplay with some replayability if you are the kind of person who wants to keep running over and over, harder and harder... But that does not really matter, I loved the characters, loved the concept and the idea of matching three in a row to get your hero through the various locations that the game has to offer, and I loved to see the boat getting bigger and bigger.  I found it to be a very well balanced game, where the quests and the runs you have to do to complete the quests scale nicely with your ability to see the combinations on the board. I enjoyed every minute of the 6 hours I played this, even though I got stuck at some points. The random factors that occur when you replay a level keep it interesting and challenging.  For me, this is the best game I have played all year (so far..) and that for only 3€! I would have happily paid 10€ for this, it is that good.  The music is amazing but limited to two songs and I garantee you they will get stuck in your head and you will find yourself humming the tune in the supermarket when trying to race old ladies to the line at the cash register...  I made a short video about the start of this game here, if you are interested:         YouTube™ Video:  What's This?! - You Must Build A Boat

There are good and bad parts of this game. The overall, however, is mostly good.   Pros:  -Retains the more complex match-three style of its predecessor, while adding new things such as traps, and new items to use while running the dungeon. -Has a monetary system, which allows for more choices in how you customize your run. -Actually has a tutorial run which explains what things are, and how to go about using them, without being too annoying about it.   Cons:  -Once you've beaten the game, and begin the hard mode, you must go through the tutorial once again. It's not as helpful the second time. -The ship is huge, and the vendors move around each time you upgrade. Finding them can be a little annoying sometimes, especially with a million monster crew members in the way.   Overall, worth the buy if you enjoyed 10,000,000.

This is a pretty good matching game! Instead of matching tiles, you must match tiles within rows or columns. While that's going on, you have an adventurer delving into a dungeon, which demands specific matches at times, so this makes for a frantic game sometimes!  It's one fault is that it's clearly made for a tablet, so there are times outside of the match game where you're meant to click repeatedly on a crate or slide something across the screen. The fault is that it's not indicated anywheres that you have to hammer down on the icon. Other than that, it's pretty simple and well done.

I've been playing videogames since 1982 and I must say I'm very very much impressed. This game has everything, kickass soundtrack (never boring), fun sounds, great sprites and characters, and an extremely simple concept very well executed. It has humor, excitement, items, gold, sacrifices to please the gods to put the odds in your favor, you name it, it's in there. If you really like games, you owe it to yourself to play this. Doesn't matter what kind of genre you prefer, if you are a gamer in the true sense of the word (not someone who jacks off on frame rates and such) you'll love this game.

I expected more out of this sequel to 10,000,000... I expected to be able to move from place to place by my own design. I thought I would be building something. But those are just mandatory, irreversible and un-customizable badges of level progression. This game is a graphical upgrade. It does have more content. It does run smoother. But I found the insincere 'You Win!' after every run, the stretched, unskippable mini-cutscenes, the insipid tutorial, the shallowness of play, too distracting to notice the things it made better... Until I went back to the original and found I really couldn't enjoy that anymore either.  I had hoped it would be so much more. It could have been so much more, if it was presented differently. Perhaps if it took some of the moments it spent intrducing pixel paper people with shallow and meaningless one-liners and used it instead to contextualize our search for the legendary artifacts that can allow us to build, not just a boat, but a FLYING SHIP.  In my heart of hearts, I am disappointed.
